Risk Management Plan

Yuba City Wholesale, Grow West

Yuba City, California



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY



ES-1.0  FACILITY ACCIDENTAL RELEASE POLICY



The owners, management, and employees of the Yuba City Wholesale, part of Grow West (herein referred to as Yuba City or the Yuba City Facility) at 2100 Everglade Road, Yuba City, California 95993 are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia or aqua ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the Facility is prepared to work with the local fire department, or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment. A detailed Emergency Action Plan - Consolidated Contingency Plan (EAP CCP) has been developed and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release.





ES-2.0  FACILITY INFORMATION



The Facility is a retail agricultural facility whose primary activity is the storage and sale of fertilizers in addition to the sale of pre-packaged agricultural chemicals to agricultural operations in the Sacramento Valley of Northern California. Applicable NAICS codes for this facility include 42491 (Farm Supplies Merchant Wholesalers).



* - Anhydrous ammonia (NH3) is received, stored, and converted to aqua ammonia (NH4OH). 

* - Aqua ammonia (NH4OH) is prepared, stored, and distributed for direct application as crop production nutrients.

* - Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and stored in two storage tanks (bullets).

* - The storage vessel information is presented below. 



     ANHYDROUS AMMONIA



* - The anhydrous ammonia storage vessels are filled to no more than 85% of shell volume. 



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA BULLET #1

* - Vessel Capacity: 15,000 gals

* - Maximum Amount of NH3: 12,750 gals

* - Mass of NH3: 65,535 lbs



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA BULLET #2

* - Vessel Capacity: 18,000 gals

* - Maximum Amount of NH3: 15,300 gals

* - Mass of NH3: 78,642 lbs



AGGREGATE TOTAL

* - Vessel Capacity: 33,000 gals

* - Maximum A

mount of NH3: 28,050 gals

* - Mass of NH3: 144,177 lbs



The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia handled is 144,177 pounds.





     AQUA AMMONIA



* - Aqua ammonia (24.3%)  is produced on-site in the facility's converter. 

* - In addition to producing aqua ammonia in the on-site converter, the facility periodically receives aqua ammonia by truck. 

* - The facility stores the aqua ammonia in steel tanks at the site. The storage tanks are connected using a piping manifold. The tank valves are kept closed unless actively being filled or drained.

ES-3.0  ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM



The Facility has implemented the following prevention program elements.



SAFETY INFORMATION:  Yuba City Wholesale ensures that information concerning covered processes and regulated substances are up-to-date and available for review by employees. The most recent review of safety information pertaining to the covered processes took place on October 6, 2020.



HAZARD REVIEW:  A hazard review of the ammonia processes is conducted every five years or as needed by changes in the processes. The most recent update of the hazard review for the anhydrous ammonia process and aqua ammonia process and storage was conducted on October 6, 2020. Results indicate that no high-risk hazards were identified through the hazard review updates.



OPERATING PROCEDURES:  Written standard operating procedures have been developed for the covered processes and are

reviewed and revised as needed. Operating procedures for the Anhydrous Ammonia Process are certified annually. The operating procedures were last revised on July 17, 2020. 



TRAINING:  The Yuba City Facility staff, as well as Grow West corporate staff, understands that incidents involving the accidental release of regulated substances can be reduced by having trained operations and maintenance staff. A training program, which incorporates specific operating procedures and safe work practices, is an essential element of an effective prevention program. The training program was last reviewed on April 15, 2020. 



The current training program is comprised of the following:

  1.  Initial employee training.

  2.  Periodic refresher training.

  3.  Training provided as a result of a new equipment addition or modification.

  4.  Competency testing involving written tests and observation following training.

  5.  Training records for each employee.



MAINTENANCE AND MECHANICAL INTEGRITY:  The maintenance program at the Facility is intended to preserve the mechanical integrity of the process equipment to minimize the potential for an accidental release. The maintenance program includes equipment inspection, preventative maintenance, recordkeeping, and training. The latest equipment inspections were conducted on April 15, 2020, and the latest review of maintenance procedures was conducted on July 17, 2020.



RMP MANAGEMENT OF CHANGE:  Operation, safety, and environmental issues must be reviewed prior to initiation of a process change to ensure that they do not compromise the operational safety and integrity of the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, and to minimize adverse effects to worker safety and public health. The Facility RMP Management of Change (MOC) procedures are used to evaluate all changes to process materials, controls, equipment, and procedures. The MOC process process was triggered on April 25, 2019. The MOC procedures were last reviewed or modified on July 1

7, 2020.



PRE START-UP SAFETY REVIEW:  The Pre Start-up Safety Review (PSSR) applies to additions or modifications to the Anhydrous Ammonia Process that require the safety information to be revised or updated. Whenever changes in affected processes are identified or planned, they must be evaluated as to the need for a pre start-up safety review. This assessment is undertaken in conjunction with the MOC review. Additionally, a pre start-up safety review is performed in conjunction with the MOC review when the proposed change requires modifications to the safety procedures. A PSSR was conducted on April 25, 2019.



COMPLIANCE AUDITS:  Periodic compliance audits to assess the effectiveness of the written plan must be conducted every three years. Records of the audits and follow-up documentation are maintained to indicate findings and resolution of findings. The most recent compliance audit was conducted on March 28, 2018.



INCIDENT INVESTIGATION:  Although no incidents involving regulated substances have occurred at the Facility in the last five years, an incident investigation program is in place. The program includes investigation requirements and reporting and would be implemented in the event of an incident. 



EMPLOYEE PARTICIPATION:  The Facility must rely upon the operational expertise and training of its employees at all levels and disciplines to ensure safe operations. The Yuba City Facility has an Employee Participation Program in place and has implemented procedures regarding engaging employees for their input, as well as ensuring access to safety documentation to ensure consideration of their knowledge and experience in all applicable areas of the prevention program. The Employee Participation procedures were last modified on September 14, 2020.



HOT WORK PERMIT:  With regard to hot work that may occur on or near the Anhydrous Ammonia Process, Yuba City Wholesale has developed a written Hot Work Permit to document the evaluation of the fire preventi

on and protection requirements. The Hot Work Permit procedure was last updated on March 18, 2019.



CONTRACTOR SAFETY:  The contractors used by the Facility for anhydrous ammonia delivery have been informed regarding the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to delivery of anhydrous ammonia to the Yuba City Wholesale Facility. The Facility has confirmed that the delivery contractors have provided the appropriate training to their drivers regarding the delivery of anhydrous ammonia. Yuba City Wholesale also qualifies contractors who are engaged in maintaining the RS systems to ensure that equipment is modified or repaired and returned to service safely. The Contractor Safety procedure was last updated on September 14, 2020.



OTHER CODE APPLICABILITY:  The Facility implements the provisions of the following guidelines, regulations, and standards for these regulated substances (partial list):



REGULATED SUBSTANCES

* - United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.38, Employee emergency response plan and fire prevention plans

* - United States Environmental Protection Agency (US EPA), 40 CFR Chapter 1, Subchapter C, Part 68, Subpart E, Emergency Response



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA

* - California Code of Regulations, Title 8, Division 1, Chapter 4, Subchapter 1, Unfired Pressure Vessel Safety Orders 

* - Compressed Gas Association (CGA) Requirements for Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, CGA 2.1-2014 edition [previously American National Standards Institute, Inc. (ANSI) K61.1, 1999 ed.]

* - United States Department of Labor, Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia



AQUA AMMONIA

* - American Society of Mechanical Engineers, 31.3 Process Piping

* - California Fire Code, Chapter 50, Hazardous Materials





ES-4.0  FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY



There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia o

r aqua ammonia during the last five years resulting in death, injuries, evacuation(s), a shelter in-place order, or property or environmental damage.





ES-5.0  THE EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM



The facility's emergency response program is developed in accordance with Section 25503, Division 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code, Hazardous Materials Business Plan requirements. The facility also developed an Emergency Action Plan (EAP) in accordance with the requirements presented in the CalARP regulations ?2745.8. The Emergency Action Plan - Consolidated Contingency Plan (EAP-CCP) was most recently updated on April 29, 2020 and will be implemented in the event of an accidental release of a regulated substance.





ES-6.0  PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY



Safety improvement is an on-going process at the Facility. Periodic evaluations will be performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. Specific changes to the anhydrous ammonia AND aqua ammonia processes at the Facility will be implemented as needed.





ES-7.0  THE WORST-CASE RELEASE AND ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS



ANHYDROUS AMMONIA WORST-CASE and ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 78,642 pounds of anhydrous ammonia; this represents the volume of the storage tank administratively limited at 85% of capacity. The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential incident), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and "D" stability modeling parameters.



AQUA AMMONIA WORST-CASE and ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIOS. The worst-case release scenario is the failure of the storage tank when filled to the greatest amount, which would release 1,668,200 pounds of aqua ammonia (equivalent to 406,075 lbs of NH3). The alternative release scenario, based on the hazard review (or a more plausible potential inciden

t), is a release from a broken 2-inch diameter pipe with an increased wind speed and "D" stability modeling parameters.
